name: Hornwort
description: Ceratophyllum demersum, commonly known as Hornwort, Coontail, or Rigid Hornwort, is a free-floating or rootless aquatic plant native to all continents except Antarctica. It belongs to the Ceratophyllaceae family and is one of the most widespread aquatic plants globally. It features whorled, needle-like, dark green leaves (1-2 cm long) arranged in dense clusters along branching stems. The leaves are stiff and forked, giving the plant a bushy, coontail-like appearance. This plant displays an upright, bushy growth habit when anchored, or can float freely. It can reach 60-120 cm in length. This aquatic plant can thrive both fully submerged and partially emersed, though it's primarily a submerged species. Unlike most aquatic plants, Hornwort has no true roots - it can be anchored in substrate or left to float. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers at leaf nodes. In nature, it grows in still or slow-moving water bodies including ponds, lakes, and slow streams. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds natural beauty, dynamic movement, and excellent water filtration to aquatic environments. It's extremely hardy and beginner-friendly.
